title: The families of British non-marine molluscs (slugs, snails and mussels)
subTitle: Version: 4th January 2012.

data: <in moist moss and leaf litter, mainly in old deciduous woodland; tolerating non-calcareous soils>
<in clean, still or slow moving water, attaching to plants, submerged timber, or the shells of larger molluscs>

<\i{}D. laeve\i0{} occurs in very wet places - fens, river banks, water meadows, etc., where it can survive submerged. The other species are found in gardens, parks, waste ground, hedges, fields, meadows, pastures, etc., and \i{}D. reticulatum\i0{} is a major agricultural and horticultural pest in lowland areas, where it is perhaps the commonest British slug>

<\i{}A. fluviatilis\i0{} lives in quick-flowing, soft or hard water, attached firmly to stones and grazing on algae and mosses. \i{}F. wautieri\i0{}, by contrast, usually attaches to submerged plants in stagnant or slowly moving water>
<species of diverse, moderately damp, usually sheltered habitats>
<coastal, found in shingle and plant dèbris around the high tide mark, sometimes submerged in brackish water, but more terrestrial than aquatic>
<in large bodies of well oxygenated, slow moving or still, hard water>
<associated with sub-surface crevices, in damp ground, in disturbed places such as gardens, old quarries and roadside verges, especially under lightly embedded stones or bricks>
<found in Kent in the shade, in lush, damp vegetation on roadside banks>
<in dry, stony situations, mainly on chalk or limestone>
<often in moss or ground litter, or lichen-encrusted walls>
<in mosses, herbage and ground litter in diverse locations - woods, fields, hedge banks, marshes, sandhills, etc.>
<in clean, well oxygenated, lowland rivers, canals and reservoirs, attaching to stones and other hard surfaces; sometimes in slightly brackish water>
<in ground litter in woods, hedgerows, etc., mainly on base-rich soils, often climbing up tree trunks or walls in wet weather>
<in a wide variety of moist, sheltered, undisturbed habitats - in coniferous and deciduous woods, mossy hedge banks, dune slacks and marshes>
<mostly in dry, sunny, open, especially calcareous places, in quarries, stone walls, hedgerows, waste ground, gardens, etc.; but a few confined to moist and sheltered or marshy places, or woodland>
<variously in still, slow or fast moving, fresh or brackish water>

<mainly naturally woodland ground dwellers or climbers, or especially in places associated with human activities (gardens, rubbish tips, roadsides, ploughed fields, etc.), in moist ground litter and herbage; nocturnal, hiding by day under logs, stones, bark, etc.>

<species of diverse wet and aquatic habitats, often on emergent vegetation or tolerant of seasonal dessication. \i{}L. truncatula\i0{}, living in wet places but mostly out of water, is notorious as the intermediate host of \i{}Fasciola hepatica\i0{}, the sheep liver fluke>
<restricted to clean, cool, fast-flowing rivers and streams at higher elevations, on sandy, gravelly or pebbly substrates; burrowing into interstices in the substrate>

<restricted to well oxygenated waters, in rivers, canals and lakes>

<the native \i{}Physa fontinalis\i0{} occurs on aquatic plants in still or running, hard or soft, unpolluted water, while the introduced \i{}Physa\i0{} species are more tolerant of de-oxygenated conditions and pollution. \i{}Aplexa hypnorum\i0{}, which can survive periodic dessiccation, is found on vegetation in swampy pools, roadside ditches and small, grassy ponds>

characters.name: <general comments>
data: <This family is probably indistinguishable from Helicidae on shell characters alone.>

<Muscular animals, broad behind and tapering to the small head, which bears two pairs of short, slender tentacles that are not swollen at their tips; with a very large radula, no jaw, and the anus at the hind end.>

The 1790 representation by Shaw (from \i{}Naturalists Miscellany\i0{}', vol. 1, no. 30) is fanciful, in that each snail posesses a single dart sac, in which the calcareous "love darts" are developed one at a time. \par{} \par{}The following quotation is from Alicia M. Cordero (2001, at http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/museum/75th/ab8.html) \par{} \par{}"Within the reproductive tract of many land snails is a dart apparatus that consists of calcareous darts and often a mucus gland. These darts, commonly referred to as "love darts" are incorporated into the courtship sequence of land snails in various ways. Sometimes the dart is ejected from the "shooter" and pierces the body wall of the "recipient." In other cases the dart is ejected from the "shooter" without entering the body of the "recipient." In some snails the dart is retained by the "shooter" and used to jab the "recipient." Many hypotheses have been presented to explain the evolutionary significance of the dart apparatus: (1) it is a calcium gift used to entice the partner to act as female; (2) it is a calcium gift used to entice the partner to act as male; (3) it is an honest signal of mate quality; (4) it facilitates species recognition; (5) it is a means of transporting chemicals to a potential mate; and (6) it is used to prevent unwanted matings. The occurrence of darts in land snails is widely distributed throughout many taxonomic groups, however, nearly all of the detailed observations of the reproductive behavior of land snails have been made on only two closely related helicoid species, \i{}Helix pomatia\i0{} and \i{}Helix aspersa\i0{}. The behavior of other species is largely unknown, but anecdotal reports show that in some species the dart may be used differently than in \i{}Helix\i0{}. In order to determine the role the dart is playing in reproduction and whether or not it has the same role within different clades, \the phylogenetic distribution of darts must be known and the behavior of more dart bearing land snails must be investigated."
